description.narrative: Standards and Trade Development Facility (STDF) är ett gemensamt initiativ kring kapacitetsbyggande och tekniskt samarbete inom SPS-området. STDF syftar till ökad koordinering i leveransen av SPS-relaterat bistånd. STDF bidrar också med projektfinansiering.

The Standards and Trade Development Facility (STDF) is a joint initiative in capacity building and technical cooperation aiming at raising awareness on the importance of sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) issues, increasing coordination in the provision of SPS-related assistance, and mobilizing resources to assist developing countries enhance their capacity to meet SPS standards.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Standards and Trade Development Facility’s (STDF) vision is: Improved SPS capacity in developing countries supports sustainable economic growth, poverty reduction, food security and environmental protection
STDF's mandate is to: - increase awareness, mobilize resources, strengthen collaboration, identify and disseminate good practice; and - provide support and funding for the development and implementation of projects that promote compliance with international SPS requirements
To obtain the vision within its mandate the focus is on following three strategic objectives, as stated in the medium-term strategy (2012-2016): 1) Enhanced collaboration on SPS-related technical co-operation 2) Improved capacity of beneficiaries to identify and prioritize SPS needs and formulate project proposals that are able to secure funding from STDF or external funding sources 3) Improved performance of beneficiaries of STDF funded projects
Based on the revised material (focus on annual reports), participation in biannual working group meetings and bilateral meetings with STDF secretariat it is assessed by Sida that the intervention has obtained a number of outputs (results) in line with the strategic objectives. STDF has continued it work a number of activities related to an enhanced collaboration on SPS-related technical co-operation such as - International Trade and Invasive Alien Species - Improving SPS decision-making for market access through the use of Multi Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA). - Promoting public-private partnership in value chain context. - Implementing SPS measures to facilitate safe trade - Information dissemination (for ex. STDF working group, STDF Website)
Eight project preparation grants were approved during 2013 (20 applications). The approved grants were mainly to Sub Saharan Africa (regional/country) region and are considered by STDF as an important mechanism to translate good ideas into concrete projects.
During 2013 five new projects were initiated, seven projects were completed and at the end of the year a total of 16 projects were under implementation. The current project portfolio has focus on LDCs and OLICs (53%). Based on assessment presented in the annual report the overall result is positive. At this stage it is not possible to assess the mid to long-term sustainability of obtained results. The ownership is considered high since it the intervention has a bottom up approach, but the investment is relatively small compared to actual challenges.
As stated previous it is assessed by Sida that the implemented activities are in line with the overall objective. However, it is difficult to follow the intervention logic. To the implemented activities lead to desired result STDF need to increase its focus on Results Based Management (RBM) from the current activity based management, to further improve the results obtained.
An external mid-term review was concluded in end of 2013 and the overall result was positive. The areas of improvement were mainly related to the need of a more RBM approach.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
